This is the start date of Nicolas Sarkozy's presidency, which provides context for the timeline of the alleged campaign financing scandal involving Libyan funds.

This period covers the critical legal process following his conviction, including the upcoming appeal decision and potential reversal of the conviction.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France (2007–2012), is the first French ex-president to be imprisoned, serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with money from Muammar Gaddafi.

Sarkozy was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who allegedly arranged secret funding from Libyan sources via intermediaries, though he denies personal wrongdoing.

The case is known as the 'Bygmalion affair' and involves allegations of illegal campaign financing, with the conviction based on the 'exceptional seriousness of the facts' despite Sarkozy's claims of innocence.
Sarkozy is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, in an isolation wing with limited contact, one hour of daily exercise, and minimal privacy.
His prison conditions include access to a small fridge, electric hob, desk, toilet, shower, and TV, with a monthly fee of €14; he also has family visits and communication rights.
Sarkozy has filed an appeal against his conviction and imprisonment, and France’s highest administrative court will deliver a verdict on the appeal in late November 2025.
He has expressed deep sorrow over the situation, calling it a humiliation for France and stating that 'truth will prevail' despite the 'crushing price' of imprisonment.

The case has sparked national debate, with President Emmanuel Macron acknowledging the symbolic significance of a former president being jailed, though not commenting directly on the judicial decision.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France from 2007 to 2012, has become the first French ex-president to go to prison after being sentenced to five years for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Though he denies personal wrongdoing, he was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who allegedly arranged secret funding through intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. Sarkozy is currently incarcerated at La Santé prison in an isolation wing, where he is held under strict solitary confinement with limited contact and exercise. He has filed an appeal against the conviction and is awaiting a final decision from France’s highest administrative court in late November 2025. The case has triggered widespread public and political debate, with President Emmanuel Macron acknowledging the symbolic significance of a former leader being jailed, and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin pledging to visit him. Sarkozy has expressed sorrow over the decision, calling it a national humiliation and maintaining his belief that truth will ultimately prevail.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
